paragraphs.text:
%md
# Agenda

* Projekthistorie Apache Zeppelin
* Zeppelin Interpreter
* Interaktive Elemente
* Visualisierungen
* Sharing data accross interpreters
* Helium!

Agenda

  • Projekthistorie Apache Zeppelin
  • Zeppelin Interpreter
  • Interaktive Elemente
  • Visualisierungen
  • Sharing data accross interpreters
  • Helium!

paragraphs.text:
%md # Apache Zeppelin ``` Web-based notebook that enables data-driven, interactive data analytics and collaborative documents with SQL, Scala and more. ```
- Apache Zeppelin Website

msg.data:
Apache Zeppelin

Web-based notebook that enables data-driven, interactive data analytics and collaborative documents with SQL, Scala and more.
- Apache Zeppelin Website

paragraphs.title: Helpers and Version Checks

paragraphs.text:
%md

## Zeppelin History

* Developed at NFLabs as part of a data analytics product named Peloton
* Zeppelin, the interactive component of Peloton, got open sourced in 2013
* Allways focused spark

### v0.5 - 2015-06
* First Apache Release
* Hive & Flink Interpreters

### v0.6 - 2016-01
* Job Management
* Notebook Authorization
* Configuration GUI + API
* Notebook Export

### v0.7 - 2017-02
* Multiuser Support
* Python Erweiterungen: Conda & Matplotlib
* Interpreter Scopes & Helium (stay tuned)

### v0.8 - WIP
* Helium Online Repository
* Graph Visualization

msg.data:
Zeppelin History

  • Developed at NFLabs as part of a data analytics product named Peloton
  • Zeppelin, the interactive component of Peloton, got open sourced in 2013
  • Allways focused spark

v0.5 - 2015-06

  • First Apache Release
  • Hive & Flink Interpreters

v0.6 - 2016-01

  • Job Management
  • Notebook Authorization
  • Configuration GUI + API
  • Notebook Export

v0.7 - 2017-02

  • Multiuser Support
  • Python Erweiterungen: Conda & Matplotlib
  • Interpreter Scopes & Helium (stay tuned)

v0.8 - WIP

  • Helium Online Repository
  • Graph Visualization

paragraphs.text:
%sh
echo -e "%table version\tcommits\t#interpreters\trelease date\ttimestamp\tFeatures
0.5\t1652\t11\t2015-06\t1435190400\tFirst Apache Release, Hive & Flink Interpreters
0.6\t2502\t19\t2016-01\t1453680000\tJob Management, Notebook Authorization, Configuration GUI + API, Notebook Export
0.7\t3255\t24\t2017-02\t1487980800\tMultiuser Support, Helium Basis
0.8\t3500\t25\t\t1506293612\tHelium Online Repo"

%md # Zeppelin interpreter ``` Zeppelin Interpreter is a plug-in which enables Zeppelin users to use a specific language/data-processing-backend. For example, to use Scala code in Zeppelin, you need %spark interpreter. ```
- Apache Zeppelin Website
* A interpreter process is a JVM process that communicates with Zeppelin daemon using thrift. * interpreter process has a n:1 relationship to an interpreter group * More then 20 interpreters for: * Big Data Frameworks: Spark (Scala, PySpark, SparkSQL, SparkR), Flink, Pig * Visualizations: Angular, Markdown * Databases: HBase, Cassandra, JDBC, PSQL * Authorization: Livy * Other Shell, file

msg.data:
Zeppelin interpreter

Zeppelin Interpreter is a plug-in which enables Zeppelin 
users to use a specific language/data-processing-backend. 
For example, to use Scala code in Zeppelin, you need
%spark interpreter.
- Apache Zeppelin Website
  • A interpreter process is a JVM process that communicates with Zeppelin daemon using thrift.
  • interpreter process has a n:1 relationship to an interpreter group
  • More then 20 interpreters for:
    • Big Data Frameworks: Spark (Scala, PySpark, SparkSQL, SparkR), Flink, Pig
    • Visualizations: Angular, Markdown
    • Databases: HBase, Cassandra, JDBC, PSQL
    • Authorization: Livy
    • Other Shell, file

paragraphs.title: Installed Interpreters
paragraphs.text:
%sh
wget -q -O - 127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter | jq -r '.body | to_entries[].key'

paragraphs.title: List interpreters
paragraphs.text:
%sh
curl -X GET -s http://127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting | jq -r '.body | [to_entries[] | .value.id + " "+ .value.name ]'

paragraphs.title: List interpreters Zeppelin-Style
paragraphs.text:
%sh
str=$(curl -X GET -s http://127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting | jq -r '.body | [to_entries[] | .value.id + "\t"+ .value.name ] | join("\n") ')
echo -e "%table id\tname\n $str"

%md
# Interpreter Scope

Definable for both, __user__ and __notebook__ level:

 * __Isolated__: each notebook will create new Interpreter process.
 * __scoped__: each notebook will create new Interpreter instance in the same interpreter process
 * __shared__: every notebook bound to the Interpreter Setting will share the single Interpreter instance

msg.data:
Interpreter Scope

Definable for both, user and notebook level:

  • Isolated: each notebook will create new Interpreter process.
  • scoped: each notebook will create new Interpreter instance in the same interpreter process
  • shared: every notebook bound to the Interpreter Setting will share the single Interpreter instance

paragraphs.title: Show interpreter settings
paragraphs.text:
%sh
curl -X GET -s http://127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting | jq -c .body[0]

paragraphs.title: Elasticsearch API
paragraphs.text:
%sh
export interpreterID=$(wget -q -O - 127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting | jq -r '.body[] | select( .name =="elasticsearch").id') 
export json=$(curl -s -X GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting/$interpreterID | jq -c '.body.name = "es" | .body.properties."elasticsearch.host" = "35.157.154.191" | .body.properties."elasticsearch.client.type" = "http" | .body.properties."elasticsearch.port" = "9200" |.body | {"name": .name, "group": .group, "properties": .properties, "interpreterGroup": .interpreterGroup, "dependencies": .dependencies,  "option": .option}')
curl -X POST -s http://127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting --data $json

%es
help

%es
count /website

%es
size 10
search website 'data2day'

%es 
index website/logs {"desc":"${myDescription}"}

paragraphs.title: Spark API
paragraphs.text:
%spark
import org.apache.commons.io.IOUtils
import java.net.URL
import java.nio.charset.Charset

// Zeppelin creates and injects sc (SparkContext) and sqlContext (HiveContext or SqlContext)
// So you don't need create them manually

val logsText = sc.parallelize(
    IOUtils.toString(
        new URL("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/krlng/techtalks/master/2017_apache-zeppelin/data/commits.csv"),
        Charset.forName("utf8")).split("\n"))

case class Commit(release: String, commit: String, created: Long, creator: String, team: Boolean, commitdate: String)

val commits = logsText.map(s => s.split(";")).map(
    s => Commit(s(0), 
            s(1),
            s(2).toLong,
            s(3),
            s(3)==s(5),
            s(4)
        )
).toDF()
commits.printSchema()

%spark
commits.registerTempTable("log")

%sql 
select release, count(1) value
from log 
group by release 
order by release

%sql
select release, team, count(1) value
from log 
group by release, team
order by release

%sql 
select release, creator, count(1) value
from log 
where release="branch-0.7"
group by creator,release
order by value

%sql 
select release, creator,value
from (select release, creator, count(1) value
from log 
group by creator,release
order by value)
where value > 50
order by release

%md
# Storage Backends
* __VFSNotebookRepo:__ local File System 
* __GitNotebookRepo:__ local file system with with local Git repository 
* __S3NotebookRepo:__ storage using Amazon S3 service 
* __AzureNotebookRepo:__ storage using Azure service

msg.data:
Storage Backends

  • VFSNotebookRepo: local File System
  • GitNotebookRepo: local file system with with local Git repository
  • S3NotebookRepo: storage using Amazon S3 service
  • AzureNotebookRepo: storage using Azure service

paragraphs.title: Enable S3 Notebook Storage
paragraphs.text:
%sh
cat <<< '
<property>
  <name>zeppelin.notebook.s3.endpoint</name>
  <value>s3.amazonaws.com</value>
  <description>endpoint for s3 bucket</description>
</property>

<property>
  <name>zeppelin.notebook.storage</name>
  <value>org.apache.zeppelin.notebook.repo.S3NotebookRepo</value>
  <description>notebook persistence layer implementation</description>
</property>
</configuration>
    ' >> $ZEPPELIN_CONF_DIR/zeppelin-site.xml
    
export AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID=
export AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY=
export ZEPPELIN_NOTEBOOK_S3_BUCKET=
export ZEPPELIN_NOTEBOOK_S3_USER=

%md

# Interactive Notebooks

* Extendable: Full HTML + JS featureset
* Using popular Angular-Style model binding
* Interactive Forms
* Interpreter Exchange

Interactive Notebooks

paragraphs.title: Using Zeppelin Context
paragraphs.text:
%spark

val myArr = Array(1,2,3,4)

class Point(val xc: Int, val yc: Int) {
   var x: Int = xc
   var y: Int = yc
}

val myObject = new Point(1,2)
z.put("myLang", "scala")
z.put("myArr", myArr)
z.put("myObject", myObject)

%pyspark
myArr = z.get("myArr")
myObject = z.get("myObject")
myLang = z.get("myLang")
print(myLang)
print(myArr)
print(myObject)

%pyspark
z.put("myPyObject",  {"myint":1,"mystr":"test"})

%pyspark

myPyObject = z.get("myPyObject")
print(myPyObject)

%md

# Share data accross interpreters

* [Angular Frontend](https://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.7.3/displaysystem/front-end-angular.html): Only for visualization
* [Angular Backend](https://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.7.3/displaysystem/back-end-angular.html): Only simple variable types
* spark-context: Only within Language-specific Spark Interpreters
* Serialization: universal, but custom work and potentially slow

msg.data:
Share data accross interpreters

  • Angular Frontend: Only for visualization
  • Angular Backend: Only simple variable types
  • spark-context: Only within Language-specific Spark Interpreters
  • Serialization: universal, but custom work and potentially slow

paragraphs.text:
%md

# Streaming Data visualization

__Ideas:__

* re-run Paragraphs from time to time: z.runParagraph() / z.run
* Watch angular scope?
* append data in visualization with JavaScript

msg.data:
Streaming Data visualization

Ideas:

  • re-run Paragraphs from time to time: z.runParagraph() / z.run
  • Watch angular scope?
  • append data in visualization with JavaScript

paragraphs.text:
%sh

export interpreterID=$(wget -q -O - 127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting | jq -r '.body[] |  del(.body.properties."zeppelin.R.render.options") | select( .name =="spark").id') 
export json=$(curl -s -X GET http://127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting/$interpreterID | jq -c '.body.name = "cluster" | del(.body.properties."zeppelin.R.render.options") | .body |  {"name": .name, "group": .group, "properties": .properties, "interpreterGroup": .interpreterGroup,"dependencies": [{"groupArtifactVersion":"org.apache.spark:spark-streaming_2.11:jar:2.2.0","local":false},{"groupArtifactVersion":"org.apache.bahir:spark-streaming-twitter_2.11:jar:2.2.0","local":false}], "option": .option}')
curl -vs -X POST http://127.0.0.1:8080/api/interpreter/setting --data $json

%cluster
import org.apache.spark.streaming.dstream.DStream
import org.apache.spark.streaming.twitter.TwitterUtils
import org.apache.spark.streaming.{Seconds, StreamingContext}
import org.apache.spark.{SparkConf, SparkContext}
import twitter4j.HashtagEntity
import scala.collection.mutable.HashMap
import twitter4j.Status


def configureTwitterCredentials(apiKey: String, apiSecret: String, accessToken: String, accessTokenSecret: String) {
  val configs = new HashMap[String, String] ++= Seq(
    "apiKey" -> apiKey, "apiSecret" -> apiSecret, "accessToken" -> accessToken, "accessTokenSecret" -> accessTokenSecret)
  println("Configuring Twitter OAuth")
  configs.foreach{ case(key, value) =>
    if (value.trim.isEmpty) {
      throw new Exception("Error setting authentication - value for " + key + " not set")
    }
    val fullKey = "twitter4j.oauth." + key.replace("api", "consumer")
    System.setProperty(fullKey, value.trim)
    println("\tProperty " + fullKey + " set as [" + value.trim + "]")
  }
  println()
}

val timeout : Long = 10000

// Configure Twitter credentials
val apiKey = "VxfLsGpIkxg0gPrGkbhCXWpxG"
val apiSecret = "ez9ebI2CrlR7zp54Mla1kYzxRBuanPyqo3ZHodBg5r5Qe5ZyMM"
val accessToken = "3236494707-LnNMwhB35S8r8c6qlyk2sL7WJQw6SPDjDVF4tnu"
val accessTokenSecret = "m6qnfv8VbfdgUVbEUla5C2EUSd9LvHVYxdfcPl5AD4TPi"

println("configure Key")

configureTwitterCredentials(apiKey, apiSecret, accessToken, accessTokenSecret)

msg.data:
warning: there was one deprecation warning; re-run with -deprecation for details
org.apache.zeppelin.interpreter.InterpreterException: Paragraph ab not found 0
  at org.apache.zeppelin.spark.ZeppelinContext.run(ZeppelinContext.java:339)
  at org.apache.zeppelin.spark.ZeppelinContext.run(ZeppelinContext.java:321)
  ... 50 elided

paragraphs.text:
%spark
import java.nio.file.{Paths, Files}

val streamingContext = new StreamingContext(sc, Seconds(5))

  val tweets: DStream[Status] =
    TwitterUtils.createStream(streamingContext, None, Array("#hadoop", "#bigdata", "#spark", "#hortonworks", "#HDP","#Wahlprogramm","#CDU","#SPD","#Trump"))

  tweets.map(tweet => {
        val latitude = Option(tweet.getGeoLocation).map(l => s"${l.getLatitude},${l.getLongitude}")
        val place = Option(tweet.getPlace).map(_.getName)
        val location = latitude.getOrElse(place.getOrElse("(no location)"))
        val text = tweet.getText.replace('\n', ' ').replace('\r', ' ').replace('\t', ' ')


       s"$location\t$text"
      }).print()
      


// Now that the streaming is defined, start it
streamingContext.start()

Thread.sleep(30000)
streamingContext.stop(stopSparkContext=false, stopGracefully=true)

## Zielsetzung

 * Neue Visualisierung mit D3
 * Daten stammen aus Spark, nicht aus Angular
 * Einfacher interaktiver Einfluss auf Visualisierung durch Nutzer

import org.apache.commons.io.IOUtils

import java.nio.charset.Charset
val diameter=z.angular("diameter")
val data = IOUtils.toString(
        new URL("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/krlng/techtalks/master/2017_apache-zeppelin/data/bubble.json"),
        Charset.forName("utf8"))
%angular

%md

# Helium

* Pluggable Backend System to extend Zeppelin. 
* JavaScript / NodeJS based 
* Installation via NPM
* 4 Types:
    * Visualization: Creating custom Chart type
    * Spell: Frontend interpreter written in JavaScript to change Input
    * Interpreter: Backend interpreter
    * Application: Packaged mixture of the three other Helium types

For more see [Documentation](http://zeppelin.apache.org/docs/0.8.0-SNAPSHOT/development/helium/overview.html)

## Setup

* __Zeppelin 0.8.0:__ Integrated Online Repository
* __Zeppelin 0.7.x:__ Manuel installation via JSON, search on [npjs.com](https://www.npmjs.com/search?q=zeppelin+helium)

For more see [Stackoverflow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/44342619/apache-zeppelin-how-to-use-helium-framework-in-apache-zeppelin)

msg.data:
Helium

  • Pluggable Backend System to extend Zeppelin.
  • JavaScript / NodeJS based
  • Installation via NPM
  • 4 Types:
    • Visualization: Creating custom Chart type
    • Spell: Frontend interpreter written in JavaScript to change Input
    • Interpreter: Backend interpreter
    • Application: Packaged mixture of the three other Helium types

For more see Documentation

Setup

  • Zeppelin 0.8.0: Integrated Online Repository
  • Zeppelin 0.7.x: Manuel installation via JSON, search on npjs.com

For more see Stackoverflow

😍😡
Think Big!Viele kleine Haken und Bugs
Pluggable-ArchitekturNoch nicht viel Verfügbar
Modernes UI-Konzept mit AngularBeschränkter Datenaustausch zwischen Interpretern
Viele Backends, viele Möglichkeitennicht ganz so flüssig in der Bedienung wie Jupyter oder RStudio

paragraphs.text: %md

name: Apache Zeppelin: Visualisierung von Big-Data and Streaming Daten
